.cell-code} import tensorflow as tf import numpy as np from tensorflow import keras import os print(tf.__version__) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2.16.1 ``` ::: ::: ![](images/1.png) # Load the data ::: {#20a770fc .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Load the Fashion MNIST dataset fmnist = tf.keras.datasets.fashion_mnist ``` ::: ::: {#ccf3d2ef .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Load the training and test split of the Fashion MNIST dataset (training_images, training_labels), (test_images, test_labels) = fmnist.load_data() ``` ::: ::: {#912098c5 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # You can put between 0 to 59999 here index = 0 # Set number of characters per row when printing np.set_printoptions(linewidth=320) # Print the label and image print(f'LABEL: {training_labels[index]}') print(f'\nIMAGE PIXEL ARRAY:\n {training_images[index]}') ``` ::: {.cell-output plt.imshow(training_images[index]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](c1w2_files/figure-html/cell-7-output-1.png){width=415 height=411} ::: ::: You'll notice that all of the values in the number are between 0 and 255. If you are training a neural network especially in image processing, for various reasons it will usually learn better if you scale all values to between 0 and 1. It's a process called normalization and fortunately in Python, it's easy to normalize an array without looping. You do it like this: ::: {#8a258b74 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Normalize the pixel values of the train and test images training_images = training_images / 255.0 test_images = test_images / 255.0 ``` ::: # define model **Sequential**: That defines a sequence of layers in the neural network. **Flatten**: Remember earlier where our images were a 28x28 pixel matrix when you printed them out? Flatten just takes that square and turns it into a 1-dimensional array. **Dense**: Adds a layer of neurons Each layer of neurons need an activation function to tell them what to do. There are a lot of options, but just use these for now: **ReLU** effectively means: if x \> 0: return x else: return 0 **Softmax** takes a list of values and scales these so the sum of all elements will be equal to 1 ::: {#b0effca7 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} model = tf.keras.models.Sequential([tf.keras.layers.Flatten(), tf.keras.layers.Dense(128, activation=tf.nn.relu), tf.keras.layers.Dense(10, activation=tf.nn.softmax)]) ``` ::: ::: {#ff5151fd .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Print the model summary model.summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} 
Model: "sequential"
``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # compile model ::: {#02f8f589 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} model.compile(optimizer = tf.optimizers.Adam(), loss = 'sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy']) ``` ::: # Callbacks ::: {#665c8921 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} class myCallback(tf.keras.callbacks.Callback): def on_epoch_end(self, epoch, logs={}): ''' Halts the training when the loss falls below 0.4 Args: epoch (integer) - index of epoch (required but unused in the function definition below) logs (dict) - metric results from the training epoch ''' # Check the loss if(logs.get('loss') < 0.3): # Stop if threshold is met print("\nLoss is lower than 0.4 so cancelling training!") print("cancelling training with:") print(epoch+1) self.model.stop_training = True # Instantiate class callbacks = myCallback() ``` ::: # train model ::: {#ecc33409 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} model.fit(training_images, training_labels, epochs=10,callbacks=[callbacks]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Epoch 1/10 1/1875 ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 7:25 238ms/step -
